case_vignette:
An 18-month-old toddler is brought to a pediatric hematologist by his father. The boy was referred to this office for prolonged neutropenia. He has had several blood tests with an isolated low neutrophil count while hemoglobin, hematocrit, and platelet count is normal. The boy was born at 39 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery. He is up to date on all vaccines and is meeting all developmental milestones. Today his complete blood count (CBC) with differential shows:
Hemoglobin: 15.5 g/dL
Platelets: 300,000 mm3
Neutrophils: 20%
Bands: 2%
Lymphocytes: 40%
Monocytes: 15%
Today, he has a heart rate of 90/min, respiratory rate of 22/min, blood pressure of 110/65 mm Hg, and temperature of 37.0°C (98.6°F). On physical exam, the child appears healthy and is within expected growth parameters for his age and sex. A bone marrow biopsy shows normal bone marrow with 95% cellularity and trilineage maturation. Flow cytometry is normal with no abnormal markers noted.
question: Which  is the most probable diagnosis in the present case?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Hematology and Oncology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been feeling generally well and don't have any symptoms today.
Have you had any changes in your weight or appetite recently?
No, my growth and appetite have been normal for my age.
Have you had any recent injuries or illnesses?
I haven't had any injuries or illnesses recently.
Have you had any family members with a history of blood disorders or cancer?
The vignette doesn't mention any family history of blood disorders or cancer.
Have you had any recent changes in your menstrual cycle?
I'm an 18-month-old toddler, so that doesn't apply to me.
Have you had any recent changes in your energy levels or sleep patterns?
I haven't had any changes in my energy levels or sleep patterns.
Have you had any recent changes in your diet or eating habits?
There have been no changes in my diet or eating habits.
Have you had any recent changes in your exercise routine or activity level?
No, my activity levels have been normal for a toddler my age.
Have you had any recent changes in your stress or anxiety levels?
As a toddler, I don't really have stress or anxiety like adults do, so there's been no change.
Have you had any recent changes in your medication regimen?
I am up to date on all vaccines, but the vignette doesn't mention any medications.
Have you had any recent changes in your medical history or any new diagnoses?
I have a condition with lasting low white blood cell counts, but no new diagnoses.
Final Diagnosis: Neutropenia.

There haven't been any changes in their energy levels or sleep patterns. There have been no changes in their diet or eating habits, and their activity levels have been normal for a toddler their age. The toddler doesn't experience stress or anxiety like adults, so there has been no change in that aspect. The toddler is up to date on all vaccines, but there is no mention of any medications. The toddler has a condition with lasting low white blood cell counts, but there have been no new diagnoses.

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I don't have any symptoms; I'm feeling healthy.
Great! Can you tell me about your medical history and any medications you are currently taking?

I've had several blood tests showing that I have a lower than normal amount of a type of white blood cell, but everything else like my red blood cells and platelets are normal. I was born normally and I'm up to date on all my vaccines. I'm developing normally for my age and I am not on any medications.
Thank you for the information. Can you tell me about your family history of blood disorders?
The information about my family history of blood disorders wasn't provided.

No problem. Based on the information you've provided, it's possible that you have a type of blood disorder called agammaglobulinemia. This is a condition where the body is unable to produce enough of a type of protein called immunoglobulin, which is necessary for the immune system to function properly. It's important to get a proper diagnosis and treatment to manage this condition.

Final Diagnosis: Agammaglobulinemia.
